title: Tricky Bash Tricks: Avoiding annoying messages from sqliterc
Ask HN: What luke a dashboard for life look like?
text:
Bear with me ...

I am, let's say, not fully in control of all aspects of my life. But most important things either are online (bank accounts and transactions, insurance documents), are on the way there (heart rate monitors) or can be pulled together.

Let's say I want to build a dashboard for life - programmatic API access only, with some ability to "nudge" - "you have not been for a run this week", or "why not email that guy you last whatsapp's a year back saying let's have a coffee"

What things should be in there? What should go beyond monitoring and into nudge-ing?

Ask HN: Where is the site about Google Chrome?
text:
I have a vague memory of seeing a site here on HN, probably not more than 2 years, but definitely more than a few months ago.

The site was written like a product release article from the Chrome team, perhaps it was even written by someone who used to work on Chrome, but it ended up explaining all the ways the browser tracks you and how bad it really is.

It had a really nice design, and if I remember correctly it had its own domain name or at least something related.

Does anyone remember this? It was the reason I started getting off Google services, but now I can't find it anywhere!

Ask HN: Is it possible to strip SSL and serve plain HTTP to local browsers?
text:
I regularly have problems accessing content due to various SSL problems, such as expired certificates, mis-matched subdomains, clock offsets, etc.

I'd like to run some kind of proxy which presents as plaintext HTTP to my browser, and goes out and gets content from the HTTPS equivalent of the same site, ignoring all SSL errors. Does anyone know if this is possible?

I am not too concerned about MITM attacks and security in general, because I browse reputatable sites through a reputable ISP in a VM.
